citations.narrative:
The facility is using tags to identify the four dogs under their control however the tags do not contain the letters “USDA”,
nor do they contain the number identifying the exhibitor. This information is required in order to correctly identify regulated
animals and allow historical as well as medical traceback. Each tag requires the letters “USDA”, numbers identifying the
state and exhibitor as well as numbers identifying the animals, embossed or stamped so it is easily readable.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
General cleaning and housekeeping were needed in the area near the dog’s outdoor runs.
o A significant accumulation of dog hair and debris could be seen at the corners as well as at the intersection between the
majority of the stairs leading down to the outdoor enclosures.
o A moderate amount of spiderwebs as well as dust could be seen hanging from the wooden roof over the dog’s runs.
o A large amount of dog hair mixed with dust and debris was layered above the vent fixed above the runs.
Areas such as these that are not adequately cleaned may create breeding and living areas for pests and may facilitate the
spread of disease. The premises shall be kept clean in order to facilitate the required husbandry practices and to protect
the health of the animals.

The medical records for the black and white Border Collie named Poppet were not complete. They did not contain the
date or the description of her previous incident requiring continued treatment with prednisone and a special diet nor did it
contain examination findings obtained during her visit with the veterinarian on March 31, 2025. The records also did not
contain the current plan for treatment and care to address her medical condition. Incomplete medical records do not allow
for adequate tracking of disease progression and do not allow verification that care is being provided per the established
plan with the veterinarian. When a problem is identified in a dog (such as disease, injury, or illness), the date and
description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures
performed are recorded in the medical records.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 4, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.51(b) 
   
Form of official tag. 
The facility is using tags to identify the four dogs under their control however the tags do not contain the letters “USDA”, 
nor do they contain the number identifying the exhibitor. This information is required in order to correctly identify regulated 
animals and allow historical as well as medical traceback. Each tag requires the letters “USDA”, numbers identifying the 
state and exhibitor as well as numbers identifying the animals, embossed or stamped so it is easily readable. 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
General cleaning and housekeeping were needed in the area near the dog’s outdoor runs.  
o A significant accumulation of dog hair and debris could be seen at the corners as well as at the intersection between the 
majority of the stairs leading down to the outdoor enclosures.  
o A moderate amount of spiderwebs as well as dust could be seen hanging from the wooden roof over the dog’s runs. 
o A large amount of dog hair mixed with dust and debris was layered above the vent fixed above the runs.  
Areas such as these that are not adequately cleaned may create breeding and living areas for pests and may facilitate the 
spread of disease. The premises shall be kept clean in order to facilitate the required husbandry practices and to protect 
the health of the animals. 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The medical records for the black and white Border Collie named Poppet were not complete. They did not contain the 
date or the description of her previous incident requiring continued treatment with prednisone and a special diet nor did it 
contain examination findings obtained during her visit with the veterinarian on March 31, 2025. The records also did not 
contain the current plan for treatment and care to address her medical condition. Incomplete medical records do not allow 
for adequate tracking of disease progression and do not allow verification that care is being provided per the established 
plan with the veterinarian. When a problem is identified in a dog (such as disease, injury, or illness), the date and 
description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures 
performed are recorded in the medical records.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 4, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
